I was bit by this as well and it's not fun. In fact, if I hadn't checked with RR, I would have wasted a lot of time on chasing a "bug" in my code, while it was really a schema change for activations which is not reflected in the cli.
CC @mbehrendt here is the issue you requested

@eweiter, @rabbah, I'm not sure we should be relying on annotations to read valuable data from. It seems like it would make more sense to update the API call to list actions so that it returns a field in the returned JSON object for each action that denotes when an action is a sequence.

As an example:

```
{
  "name": "sequenceAction",
  "sequence": true,
  "publish": false,
  "annotations": [],
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "namespace": "_"
}, {
  "name": "nonSequenceAction",
  "publish": false,
  "annotations": [],
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "namespace": "_"
}
```

@dubeejw the type of the `exec` is of course available in the action - the requested change is related to doing a `list` operation on actions which constructs a view of the actions in one's namespace. We can extract the kind from the exec and construct a new view but this results in a schema change. We will avoid this by adding the information to the annotation instead.

I'll take this one, it's a small and quick change.

@rabbah @dubeejw 
So are we just going to do this change instead of #427 since it is quicker? Either way will alleviate the issue for the UI.
closing as duplicate of #427.

@sjfink @markusthoemmes re aufs, that is correct. the commit message was "revert to auf" because I tried to move to overlay but then realized we can't use it with the 3.13 kernel in vagrant at it was only available from 3.18. I also tried to upgrade to ubuntu 16 but the vagrant image has lots of bugs so I stayed with 14.04 for now.
see https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/storagedriver/overlayfs-driver/ for details.

the following steps are planned to get this in:
- push this to master with only travis having user namespaces enabled
- existing systems (ci, dev envs, prod) do not use this feature yet and will gracefully ignore it (docker ignores the --userns=host flag if no namespaces are configured)
- push blue parts to master (can be done independently)
- once the code is in place, update docker daemons (vagrant, docker-machine, ci, prod). this should automatically pick up the feature.

What about choosing between python 2.x and 3.x ?
Would this be something that can be done declarative using one single runtime, meaning create a container with both versions of python an let user choose which one to use.

Related to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1184.

Since we have the zip file support in place, and in fact the python action proxy knows already how to deal with it, it's possible to upload a bunch of zip files containing python libraries and run them.

@markusthoemmes - Do you have time to complete the review this PR?  I'll squash/rebase when all looks good.

One question I have is how to resolve the following actor failures that occur during test (and not just in this PR's new tests).  Any ideas?

```
[2016-11-15T21:00:49.244Z] [ERROR] Outgoing request stream error [akka.actor.ActorSystemImpl:71] 
    akka.stream.AbruptTerminationException: Processor actor [Actor[akka://default/user/StreamSupervisor-521/flow-5-0-unknown-operation#-363075754]] terminated abruptly
```
Originally the value 512 was set high because the limits were global across containers.  If this new `--pids-limit` option is specific to the container, we should choose a much lower value.

@rabbah, @markusthoemmes, as far as projections for the CLI goes, is there a reason that I cannot just pass the JSON field names I want to get to the server then have the database filter out the undesired fields? That way I could just print what the backend sends to the CLI.

> That way I could just print what the backend sends to the CLI. 
> if they're "typed" in the CLI? ;)

we'd require additional support on the couchdb interface - doing a "select" requires some work.

@rabbah I was discussing this with @dubeejw  about doing a select.

When you say additional support in couchdb interface, you are talking about adding some show functions to implement the filtering?
http://docs.couchdb.org/en/2.0.0/couchapp/ddocs.html#show-functions

Then the controller can call this show function to retrieve only the fields requested.
It can be done in a number of ways in the backend, all of which require much more effort than filtering the record on the client side... not to mention the required API change.

I think what we are doing in the CLI for this PR, it's fine for now.

Should we open a new issue to add to the backlog for API changes?

I think this is a good one to add for future work, as there are clients that don't want to download a 48mb exe zip file, just to read the annotations or the default parameters for an action.

I was just asking if it was a good idea or bad idea to use couchdb show function, that way no data transfer is wasted from couchdb to controller, or controller to client.

Keep in mind that `exec` will become an attachment (one will need to explicitly fetch it). This will also be true for `logs` and maybe even `results`. So on the whole the metadata that's left may not be very big (it almost becomes isomorphic with what `list` operations provide as summaries).

In general moving filtering/select off to the datastore is of course goodness.

good point.

should we even allow piping it in, sth like `echo <json> | wsk action invoke myAction` ?

@perryibm yes it is per container. what would be a reasonable value? assuming we have about 16 actions per invoker on average would be 512 / 16 = 32. we could also calculate dynamically based on coreshare \* numcore.
This may be related to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/252.

ha @rabbah on my ride to work 😄  I realize that the zip should be an attachment, leaving the doc very very small, and not big deal to fetch the doc, and parse it client side.

I brought the concern originally with the thought that the zip will be downloaded today 
sorry for the misunderstanding 😞

Can we use this pr to make exec a JSON interface? This is just going to be an endless race.

```
> touch x.zip
> wsk action create z x.zip --kind nodejs
> wsk action get z -v
Response body received:
{
  "name": "z",
  "publish": false,
  "annotations": [],
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "exec": {
    "kind": "nodejs",
    "code": "",
    "binary": true
  },
  "parameters": [],
  "limits": {
    "timeout": 60000,
    "memory": 256,
    "logs": 10
  },
  "namespace": "guest"
}
ok: got action z
{
    "namespace": "guest",
    "name": "z",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "publish": false,
    "exec": {
        "kind": "nodejs",
        "code": ""
    },
    "limits": {
        "timeout": 60000,
        "memory": 256,
        "logs": 10
    }
}
```

The binary property is defined for some but not all action types (docker and node being two of them).
You can put the JSON in a file, and pass that filename to the -P flag.
true but here I don't want to have to create a temp file.

I'll merge this in.

I repurposed this issue and make it more general to reflect the problems with the current cli. 
Here it is another example and how to reproduce it. The example has to do with invoking an action in blocking fashion with an action that takes longer than the response timeout for blocking actions (NOTE: do not confuse the response timeout for blocking actions (i.e., how long the http connection is open) with the timeout for running the action (i.e., how long the action will be allowed to run)). Internally, the request will behave as if the action invocation was "morphed" into a non-blocking invocation. The response from the cli should indicate that this request was morphed into a non-blocking invocation. 

The response code from the REST API is a 202 and this should somehow be communicated to the cli user. 

What happens now (and steps to reproduce)

Create an action `sleep` using our `timeout.js` file and set the timeout to 120 seconds:
`action create sleep tests/dat/actions/timeout.js -t 120000`
Invoke the action blocking fashion:
`action invoke -b sleep -p payload 100000`

What I get is this:

```
ok: invoked /_/sleep with id 81df7ec28bf2480d98942fc85ed134d5
{
    "namespace": "",
    "name": "",
    "version": "",
    "publish": false,
    "subject": "",
    "activationId": "81df7ec28bf2480d98942fc85ed134d5",
    "start": 0,
    "end": 0,
    "duration": 0,
    "response": {
        "status": "",
        "statusCode": 0,
        "success": false,
        "result": null
    },
    "logs": null,
    "annotations": null
}
```

The activation record is something that the cli made up. 

What happens under the cover is this:
(same invocation as above with -v)

``` REQUEST:
[POST]  https://192.168.99.100/api/v1/namespaces/_/actions/sleep?blocking=true
Req Headers
{
  "Authorization": [...
  ],
  "Content-Type": [
    "application/json"
  ]
}Req Body
{{"payload":100000}
}
RESPONSE:Got response with code 202
Response body size is 56 bytes
Response body received:
{
  "activationId": "bacdd8898db745c3b8c3cb5c04d969f3"
}
ok: invoked /_/sleep with id bacdd8898db745c3b8c3cb5c04d969f3
{
    "namespace": "",
    "name": "",
    "version": "",
    "publish": false,
    "subject": "",
    "activationId": "bacdd8898db745c3b8c3cb5c04d969f3",
    "start": 0,
    "end": 0,
    "duration": 0,
    "response": {
        "status": "",
        "statusCode": 0,
        "success": false,
        "result": null
    },
    "logs": null,
    "annotations": null
}
```

As I already mentioned, the activation record is bogus and the response code is lost in translation.

Same command as above, run locally with `-d` as requested:

```
[/go-whisk/whisk.NewClient]:070:[Inf] Disabling certificate checking.
[mmands.parseQualifiedName]:096:[Inf] Qualified entityName: sleep
[mmands.parseQualifiedName]:097:[Inf] Qaulified namespace: _
[sk-cli/commands/action.go]:159:[Inf] Parsing parameters: []string{"{\"payload\": 100000}"}
[mmands.getJSONFromStrings]:145:[Inf] Created map 'map[payload:100000]' from '{"payload": 100000}'
[k.(*ActionService).Invoke]:233:[Inf] HTTP route: actions/sleep?blocking=true
REQUEST:

  ],

  ]
}Req Body

}

RESPONSE:Got response with code 202
Response body size is 56 bytes

  "activationId": "e8c7e30373964a328725e51526e4d478"
}
[-whisk/whisk.(*Client).Do]:233:[Inf] Response body received (ASCII quoted string):
"{\n  \"activationId\": \"e8c7e30373964a328725e51526e4d478\"\n}"
[hisk.parseSuccessResponse]:327:[Inf] Parsing HTTP response into struct type: **whisk.Activation
[hisk.parseSuccessResponse]:334:[Inf] Successful parse of HTTP response into struct type: **whisk.Activation
ok: invoked /_/sleep with id e8c7e30373964a328725e51526e4d478
```

PG1 852. Ready for merge if you don't have anymore comments, @joachimvaldez.

As I was writing some tests, the following comment came to mind
- Have the controller validate that the specified API action (not the routemgmt action, but the user action) actually exists and namespace/auth has access to it before calling the routemgmt create action.

For the case of the blocking invocation that is internally translated into a non-blocking one, the cli should communicate the change to the user. One way to do it: the response from the cli should be something along the lines:

```
request could not be satisfied on time, switched to non-blocking invocation.
ok invoked <action_name> with id bacdd8898db745c3b8c3cb5c04d969f3
```

part of fixing this, please add a test.
